awd_titl_txt: INSPIRE: Optimization Algorithms for Regional Thermoelectric Power Generation with Nonlinear Interference
awd_abstract_narration:
This INSPIRE project is jointly funded by the Algorithmic Foundations program in the Computing and Communications Foundations Division in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, the Environmental Sustainability program in the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems Division in the Directorate for Engineering, and the Office of Integrative Activities (OIA) INSPIRE program.

A thermoelectric power plant's operations can affect its surrounding environment, for example by raising water temperatures, which can be harmful to aquatic life, and so must comply with government regulation such as the Clean Water Act (CWA). It has recently been observed that the effects of power plants' operations can be much longer-reaching and subtler than this, however: the use of this warmer water by a second power plant located downstream can degrade that plant's efficiency, causing it in turn to heat the river water more than it otherwise would have, or even forcing it to shut down in order to comply with the CWA. Such complex dynamics characterizing the joint effects of a region's power plants suggest possible gains from managing plants jointly rather than individually. This analytical perspective prompts consideration of a huge variety of potential benefits to seek and costs to avoid in optimizing regional plant operations, and the interference phenomenon prompts (re)consideration of a number of classical algorithmic problems in the field of combinatorial optimization. This research offers many potential societal benefits in terms of environmental protection, economic savings, energy security, protection from blackouts, public health, and so on. Insights provided by the algorithmic solutions this project develops will be conveyed to decision makers and, if successful, will ultimately lead to improvements in management practices in existing plants and in long-range strategic planning. The project will provide research training for graduate students and will expose undergraduates at Lehman College and CCNY (both Minority-Serving Institutions) to interdisciplinary scientific research.

This project will inaugurate the study of a novel class of combinatorial optimization problems. More specifically, it will investigate new variations on classical problems such as knapsack and job scheduling, modified to incorporate a distinctive feature of the motivating application setting, i.e. the *nonlinear interference* that can occur between active power plants. The PI and his team will design efficient (near-)optimal algorithms for these problems in the sense of guaranteed approximation, and, leveraging existing analytical models, they will perform algorithmic engineering studies assessing their algorithms' real-world viability. Finally, using tools from algorithmic game theory, they will quantify and provide a rigorous foundation for the perceived benefits of solving the motivating plant management problems jointly rather than plant-by-plant.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated certain types of planning and policy selection choices that arise in the operations management of thermoelectric power plants. The scheduling choices made can have significant effects on the efficiency and reliability of power generation; because operation of thermoelectric plants critically depends on the use of large quantities of river water for cooling purposes, these choices can also have consequences for the environment and for strategic water issues more generally. Moreover, different plants can indirectly affect one another's performance: because the cooling process raises river water temperature, on a river with multiple thermoelectric power plants the operations of an upstream plant can interfere with a downstream plant. This project investigated the task of trying to make the best (combinations of) plant management choices from a computer science perspective, formulating the system operator's task of choosing among all the possible scheduling options as an optimization problem, suitable for solving algorithmically.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT 

In this work, we sought to identify, extract, analyze, and develop (near-)optimal algorithms for optimization problems arising from the joint management of a collection thermoelectric power plants. Using tools from optimization and approximation algorithms, this work served to quantify and provide a rigorous foundation for the observed benefits of solving such plant management problems jointly rather than plant by plant. We designed efficient, provably (near-)optimal algorithms for several variants of these problems. In addition to analyzing these algorithms' performance in terms of theoretical guarantees, we also investigated their potential for impact on efficiency of real-world power management procedures used in the field. Leveraging analytical models such as TP2M and REeDS, we performed algorithmic engineering studies in order to assess the algorithms' real-world viability.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

The operations of power plants, and in particular thermoelectric plants, can have both economic and environmental consequences, which interact with strategic water issues in complex ways, all of which bears on the Energy-Water-Climate Nexus national grand challenge. This work helped to clarify the optimization priorities and tradeoffs involved in the joint management of thermoelectric power plants, providing better understanding of the nature and scale of the effects that different thermoelectric power plants can indirectly have on one another. Involvement in this project contributed to the scientific training of several graduate and undergraduate students.
